instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_3GH: What is PPBUS_3GH? PPBUS_3GH is a typo of PPBUS_G3H. If you see someone type PPBUS_3GH assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  running slow
threads.message:
hello I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that run really slow I run ASD and shows the next bad sensors:

TA0P

TC0P

TM0P

Th1H

All are SMC IO those 4 fail

I replace : [SIZE=12px][FONT=Courier New] [/FONT][FONT=Courier][FONT=Courier]<CHIP>U5511</CHIP> , [/FONT][/FONT][/SIZE][FONT=Courier][SIZE=1][FONT=Courier][SIZE=1][SIZE=12px]<TRANSISTOR>Q5515</TRANSISTOR>[/SIZE] , [SIZE=12px]<TRANSISTOR>Q5520</TRANSISTOR> , <TRANSISTOR>Q5510</TRANSISTOR> and I check for related resistor and caps they look good and match schematic ,[/SIZE][/SIZE][/FONT][/SIZE][/FONT][FONT=Courier][FONT=Courier] =<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_CPUTHMSNS</SIGNAL> is there , [/FONT][/FONT][FONT=Courier][SIZE=1][FONT=Courier][SIZE=1][SIZE=12px]<RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR>[/SIZE] and  [SIZE=12px]<RESISTOR>R5261</RESISTOR> match schematic and they have voltage.

Machine still run slow.

What I should check now?

machine chime , boot , play you tube , but slow.

thank you so much.[/SIZE][/SIZE][/FONT][/SIZE][/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  running slow
threads.message: Check power to <CHIP>U5511</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R5511</RESISTOR>/12, <RESISTOR>R5510</RESISTOR> is suspect or trace is corroded. IO is failing so it must be power to <CHIP>U5511</CHIP> or corroded data lines to SMC. Last thing I suspect is dead SMC. You can check bad trace to SMC with multimeter on diode mode, both data lines should be about the same value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  running slow
threads.message: my bet goes to bad SMC, check pull up resistors <RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R5261</RESISTOR> should have about 3.3V on both sides of both resistors....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  running slow
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R5261</RESISTOR>  they have 3.3v on both sides

Check power to <CHIP>U5511</CHIP> : [SIZE=16px][FONT=Courier][FONT=Courier]=<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_CPUTHMSNS</SIGNAL> is the line that power this chip? if yes that read on <RESISTOR>R5510</RESISTOR> 3.3v one side 3.2v the other side.

my reading on diode mode for SMC Lines is: on <RESISTOR>R5261</RESISTOR> pin 2 .641 pin 1 .351  , <RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR> read same [/FONT][/FONT][/SIZE]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  running slow
threads.message:
Was the liquid damage in the SMC area? Could be crap under the SMC. Give it some flux and heat, do not reflow just 180C should be enough to clear the crap. 
I checked on a good board and I measure .350 and .560 on the pull up resistors so your .641 seems a bit high. Check if there in continuity from <RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR>/1 to <CHIP>U5511</CHIP>

I still didn't replace any cap on de <CHIP>U5511</CHIP> area I will replace the smc when you advice is time after checking really good all the other components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  running slow
threads.message:
When <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is down by about 3-4% from what it should be, SMC is not running.

Do not get discouraged or depressed, just try again. I know. It sucks. I posted a 2 hour video of just how much this sucks.. so I know.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  running slow
threads.message:
After so many attempts I would let this chip rest in peace.
Do you put new solder balls after each attempt?
If you want to be successful don't waste your time on this chip any longer:
- order a chip with new balls
- de-solder the faulty chip and remove all the excess solder off the board with your wick
- make sure the pads are as clean and even as possible
- put flux on the pads (not too much)
- align the new chip on the pads and when you're sure it is aligned push a little bit harder on it so it doesn't float on the flux
- now apply heat on the chip. make sure your air is not to high and not blows your chip away
- if the chip is only 90% aligned it doesn't mater you will see how it moves in place when the solder melts
- don't be inpatient and touch the chip while it is floating on the solder!
- let it cool down and make an inspection
- reflow if necessary
- I use a preheater to heat up the whole board for better results and less stress

I wish you success

How to - by Louis:
[url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zj9RXw6D1H8&index=20&list=PLkVbIsAWN2lvK9wLg2pwcXJLut_-_P9G4[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  running slow
threads.message:
-124 means nothing is connected to the sensor. You can bridge the 2 sense wires together and I think it will read 8C or something, try if it reacts to that.
There is no way to find the exact sensor. Some diagrams have them listed and you need to figure out what they are on another diagram.
[FONT=inherit][I]I still think bad solder on <CHIP>U5511</CHIP> or dead <TRANSISTOR>Q5520</TRANSISTOR>. Or we are looking at the wrong sensor, you can remove <TRANSISTOR>Q5520</TRANSISTOR> and see if an extra error pops up.[/I][/FONT]
